intro: Dactylorchis incarnata var. serotina, commonly known as the late-flowering pink beardtongue, is a perennial orchid native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, upright stems and clusters of pink to purple flowers that bloom late in the growing season. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are typically arranged in a basal rosette. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it a hardy addition to rock gardens or native plant landscapes. Its unique floral structure and extended blooming period make it a valuable species for pollinators and botanical enthusiasts.
